overview: From 2025-09-21 to 2025-09-28, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 53 new PRs (45 merged), 37 new issues, and 67 active contributors.

topIssues.title: op-test-sequencer: add to devnet env and kurtosis
topIssues.author: protolambda
topIssues.body:
Depends on #15263  and #15264 
 
- [ ] Add op-test-sequencer to devnet env inventory typing in devnet-sdk
- [x] Add op-test-sequencer to kurtosis as optional service. Like the supervisor, do not group it inside of an L2 chain, but make it flexible as global service, and allow multiple instances.
- [ ] Add op-test-sequencer to `devstack/sysext` package, by detecting it in the env, and adding it to the hydrated system frontend, like the other services are.

topIssues.title: enable flashblocks on sunnyside sequencers.
topIssues.author: yashvardhan-kukreja
topIssues.body: After the success of enablement of flashblocks on all the sequencers of mainnet, enable them on sunnyside, with basic healthiness criteria.

topIssues.title: op-batcher: prepare for Fusaka
topIssues.author: geoknee
topIssues.body:
When Fusaka activates on L1, the batcher needs to behave differently. 

It needs to send blob transactions with _cell proofs_ rather than _blob_ proofs. See [this doc for more info](https://www.notion.so/oplabs/Fusaka-Blob-Tx-Offchain-compatibility-26bf153ee1628013bb54dccdca75ccbc). We should bring in code from upstream geth to support this, we may need to bake it in if it gets removed from upstream geth.

We probably need to coordinate activating the new behaviour with Fusaka activation (cell proofs unlikely to work before Fusaka). 

For a v0, we should just add a CLI flag to control the type of transaction used. This allows us to successfully defend Fusaka by having chain operators restart their batcher close to Fusaka activation with the new behavior enabled. 


We also need to consider [EIP 7825,](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7825):  what if calldata batches use too much gas? Also, the intrinsic costs change, which could affect the minimum.

topPRs.title: op-dispute-mon: node endpoint error metrics
topPRs.author: pauldowman
topPRs.body:
This PR adds the following prometheus metrics to dispute-mon:

* Gauge of total number of endpoints that returned an error (other than not found) during the last update cycle - note this is the number of rpcs that had at least 1 failure, so if the same rpc gives an error on 10 games that still counts as 1.
* Gauge of total number of failures (other than not found) in the last update cycle. This counts each error from an rpc as a new event even if the rpc is the same (so one rpc giving 10 errors sets this to 10).
* Gauge of the total number of games where some nodes reported not found and others had the block in the last update cycle.
* Gauge of the total number of games where some nodes reported the output root as safe and others as unsafe in the last update cycle
* Gauge of the total number of games where nodes returned different expected output roots in the last update cycle

Reviewers might want to look at each commit separately, there's one for each metric.

Closes #11020

topPRs.title: op-node,op-program,kona: embed L1ChainConfig in configuration
topPRs.author: geoknee
topPRs.body:
Since [Ecotone](https://specs.optimism.io/protocol/ecotone/l1-attributes.html), the L1BlockInfo deposit transaction couples the L2 state transition with the blob base fee of the l1 origin. The blob base fee is not part of the block, but rather computed from `block.excessBlobGas` with an [off-chain formula which varies according to which fork is active on L1.](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/blob/51614a3dc4af4a2b503ba178e0799013e6774613/consensus/misc/eip4844/eip4844.go#L180-L197)

For the L2 state to accurately reflect the blob base fee of the l1 origin, it is necessary to provide the L2 consensus client information about the fork schedule of the L1 which it derives from.

This PR does that in a relatively lightweight way:
* for chains with a recognized l1 chain ID (such as all chains in the superchain registry), lookup the l1 chain config (either for Mainnet or Sepolia) using op-geth as a library. This information needs to be kept updated as new L1 forks (including BPO or blob parameter only forks) are scheduled in upstream geth and brought in through upstream merges. When this happens, we need to update the absolute prestate for the proofs system
* for custom chains (think devnets, test environments, chains which are not in the superchain registry) it is required to pass the l1 chain config via a new CLI flag. This can be directly JSON encoded or embedded in a `genesis.json` file.
* Does something similar for the op-program, which does not allow information to be passed at runtime but instead via filesystem embedding
* Also includes changes in this direction for kona

I avoided embedding the l1 chain config inside the `rollup.Config`, as that would require changing all of the data in the superchain registry.

This is a backwards compatible change which also makes the derivation pipeline compatible with post-Fusaka L1s.

The diff is quite large, mostly because there is a lot of boilerplate to change both in production and test code.

Closes #17493
